results.title: Animal Farm by George Orwell. The Grapes of wrath by John Steinbeck
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I couldn’t put it down - hooked on books. Classroom classics”.
Classroom Classics utilises material from film versions of literary works to encourage students to seek out, read, and analyse intelligently books they are studying in class. In this episode two important political novels of the twentieth century are discussed. George Orwell’s “Animal Farm” is a caustic satire about the corruption of idealism. John Steinbeck’s “The Grapes of Wrath” is a powerful novel about the effect of the 1930’s Depression on the American poor. Both novels are analysed in relation to the historic conditions that fed the writers’ art, passion and anger.

results.title: Animal farm
results.creator_credit: Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films, John Halas and Joy Batchelor
results.brief_description: This famous animated version of “Animal Farm” is based on George Orwell’s political fable which examines allegorically the illusion and disillusion of a Utopian society. Rated: PG

results.title: Animal Crackers
results.brief_description: This is one of the Marx Brothers’ funniest films, with Groucho starring as the big, wild, game hunter causing more delirium in high society than in the jungle! A painting is stolen in a high society home, and the Marx Brothers are there to lend their confusing hand to solve the crime.

results.title: Animal behaviour: a first film
results.creator_credit: Norman Bean and Norman Bean Films
results.brief_description: Animals have behaviour patterns that are caused by stimuli. The film is open ended as the viewer is left to work out the stimuli for various types of behaviour. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Animal behaviour
results.creator_credit: Chris O'Rourke, Victoria. Ministry of Education and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Stewart Jackel, senior education officer of Zoo Education Services, and Year 12 students from Prahran High School discuss the adaptive nature of animal behaviour and the ways in which animal structures are used to assist survival.

results.title: Animal babies grow up
results.brief_description: Puppies and piglets, a colt and a kangaroo, opossums, woodchuck, snakes, fish, birds, tadpoles and caterpillars illustrate how animals are born, and the stages they undergo as they develop. Important life science concepts include the extent of care given by the mother, feeding habits of the young, and that while some may not look like their parents at birth, all grow up to resemble them. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Animal alphabet parade
results.creator_credit: Stewart Hardy Films and John Williams
results.brief_description: An animated production that presents a segment on each letter of the alphabet. A magician introduces a rapid succession of words beginning with the particular letter. Despite the fact that the words used are phonetically quite complex, the overall rich choice of language could be a useful tool for language development. Note that the writing technique demonstrated for each letter is not that used for Victoria.

results.title: Anima mundi
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Taub, Bvlgari, World Wildlife Fund and Godfrey Reggio
results.brief_description: This world is indeed a living being endowed with soul and intelligence. This quote from Plato’s “Timeus” guides the spirit of this ravishing short film. An original music score by Philip Glass, based on indigenous music from around the globe, is the soundtrack to a compilation of some of the world’s finest film footage of the animal kingdom. From mammals to reptiles, then to the mysterious worlds beneath the ocean, the film is a poetic celebration of the diversity and beauty of animal life. The music, integral to this film without dialogue, combines orchestral instruments with rhythms and sounds from across the globe. From the majesty of a lion’s face, to the intimate wonder of a cell multiplying, this is an excellent teacher of the rich legacy nature has left our planet. A co-production between Italy and the United States, “Anima Mundi” was partly funded by the World Wildlife Fund to celebrate their Biological Diversity Campaign.

results.title: Angus lost
results.creator_credit: Evergreen Productions, Firehouse Productions, John Sturner and Gary Templeton
results.brief_description: Angus is a very curious, clever Scottish terrier, whose curiosity gets him into a number of close scrapes. This is a live-action, non-verbal adaptation of Marjorie Flack’s classic book and is sure to delight audiences both young and old.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Evergreen Productions, Firehouse Productions, John Sturner and Gary Templeton
